columns.text: In this instance, we are transferring a $15,000 credit card balance from our current card to a new credit card account; the present credit card's annual rate is 17.5%, while the new card's rate is only 8.9%. In this case, we'll figure out how quickly we can pay off the loan if we plan to make $250 monthly payments on the new card. We'll also evaluate how quickly we can pay off the debt if the new card imposes a 2% fee on balance transferred.

To solve the problem, we will analyze the following details from the exercise:

| Particulars           |         |
|-----------------------|---------|
| Loan amount           | $15,000 |
| Current card interest | 17.5%  |
| New card interest     | 8.9%    |
| Monthly payments      | $250    |

To begin with, we'll calculate and compare the number of months required to fully pay the balance on the current credit card and in the new credit card to see how soon we can finish paying off the loan balance, assuming a monthly payment of $250.

In calculating the number of months required, we will use the spreadsheet function known as NPER.

The NPER is a spreadsheet financial function that determines the number of loan periods depending on the interest rate, current value, and periodic payment.

The following syntax can be used to use the NPER on a spreadsheet:

$$\begin{aligned}
NPER&=(\text{rate},pmt,pv,[fv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$


Where:


$pmt$, which represent the constant payment\
$pv$, which means the present value\
$fv$, which refers to the future value\
$type$, which indicates the basis of the calculation, either year-end or beginning of the year
Let's start by calculating the number of monthly payments on the current credit card, with a 17.5% annual interest rate, using the loan amount as the present value.

Now, let's calculate the number of months to pay the loan on our current credit card on a spreadsheet. For the function to perform correctly, the monthly payment must be negative.

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/d60f8042-692f-4c26-ab23-2b998aba5ea8-1644063983469617.png)

As a result, if the monthly payment is $250, the loan on the present credit card will be paid off in 144 months.
Next, let's now compute the number of months it will take to pay off the $15,000 balance with a $250 monthly payment on a new credit card with an annual interest rate of only 8.9%.

Let's now determine the number of months required in the new credit card to pay the loan. Note that the monthly payment should be negative for the function to perform correctly.

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/4bf01ebe-ebaa-45fa-8f89-b617cfc955d9-1644064873190632.png)

Based on our calculation, the number of months it will take to pay the loan in the new card is 80 months.

Finally, based on the results of our calculations, the number of months required to pay off the loan on both the current and new credit cards demonstrates that the loan is paid off faster on the new credit card.

We will decrease the number of months required on the new credit card from the number of months needed on the previous credit card to determine how quickly the loan will be paid on the new credit card. As a result, we'll employ the following formula.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{TS on the NC} &= \text{Months required on the OC}-\text{Months required on the NC}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:
- TS refers to the time saved
- NC is the new card
- OC means the old card.
For the following calculation, we'll evaluate how quickly we can pay off the loan on the new card supposed the new credit card charges a 2% fee on the loan balance transfer.

We will use similar applications and formulas from the previous calculations in this calculation. Except, in this case, we will consider the value of the 2% charge from transferring the balance from the old card.

First, let's determine the value of the fee charged by the credit card. We will multiply the 2% on the loan amount transferred from the old card. We will use the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Credit card charge} &= \text{Balance transfered}\times2\%

\end{aligned}$$

Let's now calculate the value of the fees on the new credit card.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Credit card charge} &= \$15,000\times2\%
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\$300}
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the value of the credit card fee from transferring of balance is $300.

Since the credit card fee requires another payable, we will add the credit card charge to the transferred loan balance to determine the present value we will consider in calculating the number of months to settle the loan.

Let's now calculate the present value of the loan in the new card considering the 2% credit card charge.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Present value} &= \$15,000+\$300
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\$15,300}
\end{aligned}$$

As a result, we'll use $15,300 as the present value to figure out how long the new credit card will take to pay off the loan.

The interest rate is comparable to what was calculated previously. The new credit card's annual rate of 8.9% is divided by 12 to produce the monthly rate needed for the calculation. As a result, we'll look at the monthly rate of 0.74%.

Considering the previous steps, we will view the following details in calculating the number of months it will take in the new credit card with a 2% transfer charge.

| Particulars      |         |
|------------------|---------|
| Present value    | $15,300 |
| Monthly interest | 0.74%   |
| Monthly payments | $250    |

Let's now calculate the number of months it will take in the new credit with a 2% charge to settle the loan balance. As previously noted, the monthly payment is negative for the function to work correctly. 

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/0ceed640-bb65-40f6-acaa-bc40a5c1bacc-1644068091230867.png)

As seen in the above calculation, the number of months required to pay the loan on the new credit card with a 2% charge is 82 months.

Finally, because the new card has a lower interest rate, the loan debt of $15,000 can be paid off faster on the new card than the old card by 64 months if we pay $250 each month. Even if the new credit card charges 2% for balance transfers, we can still pay off the loan in 62 months faster than the current card.
